metadata.title: Reversible aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation/hydrogenation of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocycles over AlN supported redox cobalt catalysts

Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of Co 2p in (a) Co3O4/AlN and (b) Co/AlN; Al 2p in (c) Co3O4/AlN and (d) Co/AlN; N 1s in (e) Co3O4/AlN and (f) Co/AlN, and O 1s in (g) Co3O4/AlN and (h) Co/AlN. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 UV–vis DRS spectra (a) and Kubelka-Munk plots (b) of the tested samples. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR curves of the unreduced supported Co3O4 (a) and reduced supported Co (b) catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effects of (a) reaction temperature, (b) reaction time, and (c) solvent on the catalytic performances of aerobic oxidation dehydrogenation of THQ. Reaction conditions: THQ 1 mmol, 4% Co3O4/AlN 0.02 g, solvent 2 mL, O2 5 atm. (ME is methanol, DMF is dimethylformamide, MST is mesitylene, IPA is isopropyl alcohol, EA is ethyl acetate, CY is cyclohexane.). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effects of (a) reaction temperature, (b) reaction pressure (PH2), (c) reaction time, and (d) solvent on the catalytic performances of 4% Co/AlN catalyst on hydrogenation of quinoline. Reaction conditions: quinoline 0.1 mmol, 4% Co/AlN 0.04 g, solvent 5 mL. (IPA is isopropyl alcohol, ME is methanol, ET is ethanol, THF is tetrahydrofuran, DMF is dimethylformamide, DCM is dichloromethane, and EA is ethyl acetate.). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Reusability studies of 4% Co3O4/AlN in aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ (a) and Co/AlN in hydrogenation of quinoline (c), and hot filtration experiments of Co3O4/AlN (b) and Co/AlN (d). The reaction conditions of (a, b) and (c, d) were similar to those of entry 2 in Table 2 and entry 1 in Table 4, respectively. Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Chemical Additives for Industry College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi’an 710021 China Graphical abstract N-heterocycles with quinoline and tetrahydroquinoline structures are highly important in pharmaceutical and chemical industries, and their highly efficient mutual transformations are vital but still challenging. In the present work, AlN supported redox cobalt catalysts (Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN) were prepared, which could achieve the reversible aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation/hydrogenation of N-heterocycles with good performances. The catalytic performances were stem from the strong interaction between Co species with AlN support, which were confirmed by the characterizations of Raman, XPS, UV–vis DRS, and H2-TPR etc. Both of the catalysts showed good stabilities and reusabilities for the titled reactions. Besides, the gram-scale experiments achieved with good yields to corresponding products, revealing the present protocol possesses great potential applications in industry. The strategy of using redox Co-based catalyst not only provides a potential catalyst for the reversible hydrogenation/oxidative dehydrogenation reactions but also replenishes methods for constructing of other redox catalyst, especially with AlN as a carrier. Keywords AlN Cobalt catalysts Dehydrogenation Hydrogenation N-heterocyclic compounds Introduction Quinoline and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (THQ) derivatives are the integral intermediates of numerous pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, alkaloids and fine chemicals [1,2]. Some well-known prescribed and potential drugs contain quinoline or tetrahydroquinoline motif, including chloroquine, bulaquine, galipeine, cuspareine, and galipinine (Scheme 1 ) etc. [3,4]. Based on its wide utilization, the synthesis of these N-heterocycle chemicals is highly important and has caught much attention in recent years. One feasible way for the synthesis of quinolines is the dehydrogenation of corresponding 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinolines, which is a very famous dehydrogenation reaction in organic chemistry. However, removing the hydrogen atoms from adjacent atomic centers of a saturated organic molecule included 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinolines is difficult because the dehydrogenation reaction is a thermodynamically uphill process [5]. Lots of metal catalysts included Ru [6], Co [7], Mn [8], V [9], Os [10], and NiMn bimetallic [2] etc. have been developed and assessed with a high activity in the dehydrogenation reaction. On the other hand, the reversible reaction of dehydrogenation, i.e., hydrogenation of quinolines can selectively provide THQs. Resemble to the hydrogenation reaction, a variety of catalysts contained Pd [11], Rh [12], Au [13], Co [14], and t BuOK [15] etc. have been used with excellent performances in the hydrogenation reaction. Compared with the catalysts in dehydrogenation/hydrogenation unidirectional reaction, the development of a single catalyst that can achieve both of the (oxidative) dehydrogenation and hydrogenation reversible reactions has been arousing considerable interest [16,17]. The homogeneous catalysts include pyridonate Cp*Ir complex [18,19], NHC-based iridium catalyst [1] etc. exhibited high activities under relatively mild reaction conditions. However, these homogeneous catalysts are difficult to be separated from the reaction mixture and then reused, which hinder their further applications. Besides these homogeneous catalysts, the heterogeneous ones especially with noble metal are also applied to these reactions and offered acceptable catalytic performances. For example, the Pd nanowire catalyst could achieve the dehydrogenation of THQs smoothly at a very low temperature of 40 °C and the hydrogenation of quinolines at 80 °C [20]. Other catalysts, such as Pt/C [21], Pd NPs/SBA-15 [22], and PdNi@MIL-100(Fe) [23] etc. were also successfully evaluated for these reactions. The noble metal catalysts, however, are very expensive and their utilization increases the cost of the processes. The Cu/TiO2 catalyst with noble metal-free was developed, but the reaction suffered from the higher temperature condition (150 °C) [24]. Recently, a Ni-based catalyst (Ni-phen@SiO2-1000) offered higher activities both in dehydrogenation at 100 °C and hydrogenation at 120 °C [9]. The Co-based catalysts included Co-Phen@C [5] and Co@NGS-800 [25] have also been developed, however, the additives such as K2CO3, t BuOK etc. with equal molar ratio to substrates were needed for the partial dehydrogenation reaction. Notably, the atomically dispersed Co sites (ISAS-Co/OPNC) could catalyze the dehydrogenation of tetrahydroquinolines at 120 °C and transfer hydrogenation of quinolines with formic acid at 100 °C [23]. Although a great progress has been made, to develop an efficient heterogeneous catalyst with non-noble metal, operating under mild additive-free conditions is highly demanding [26–28]. Aluminum nitride (AlN) is a wide-band-gap semiconductor with good thermal stability and high thermal conductivity, and does not show acidic properties [29,30]. Based on these properties, AlN has attracted much attention for the potential application in ultraviolet optoelectronic devices and high-temperature electronic applications [31,32]. It can be also widely used as a thermal stable catalyst, support and/or acidic regulator in heterogeneous catalysis [33]. For example, He and coworkers have found the presence of AlN could reduce the sintering and acidity of Ni/γ-Al2O3-AlN catalyst, which further showed an enhanced catalytic performance than Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/AlN in partial oxidation of methane [34]. Co-based catalysts are widely used in oxidation/hydrogenation reactions [35–38]. Herein, Co3O4/AlN catalyst was prepared by a simple impregnation method and applied in catalyzing the aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ with a high efficiency, while its reduced form (Co/AlN) could achieve the hydrogenation of quinolines smoothly. The strong interaction between Co species and AlN support closely related to the catalytic performances. Potentially, the developed redox Co-based catalysts show their applications in industry and may be extended to catalyze the transformation of other N-heterocyclic compounds. Experimental section Materials and methods Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%), quinoline (96.0%), and γ-Al2O3 (99.99%) were purchased from Aladdin. AlN (99.5%), BN (99.9%), THQ (98%+), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (99.99%), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (99.0%), Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (98%+), and La(NO3)3·6H2O (99.9%) were purchased from Adamas. Isoquinoline (97%+) was purchased from Accela ChemBio Co., Ltd. SiO2 was purchased from Qingdao Ocean Chemical Co., Ltd. CeO2 (99.9%) was purchased from Beijing Innochem Science & Technology Co.,Ltd. O2 (99.999%), H2 (99.99%), N2 (99.99%), He (99.999%), 10% H2/Ar, and 2% O2/He were purchased from Xi’an Teda Cryogenic Equipment Co., Ltd. All other chemicals were analytically grade and obtained from commercial companies and used without further purification. Catalyst preparation The Co catalysts loaded on various supports were synthesized by an impregnation method. Taking the 4% Co3O4/AlN catalyst as an example, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.198 g, 0.68 mmol) was dissolved into 1 mL water under stirring to form a homogeneous solution. The solution was then dropped into 1 g AlN support, and the mixture was held at ambient temperature for 12 h. After that, it was dried at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by calcination at 650 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. Upon calcination, the catalyst denoted as Co3O4/AlN was obtained. The Co metal loading was monitored by ICP-OES. The Co3O4/AlN catalysts with different loadings, Co3O4/BN, Co3O4/CeO2, Co3O4/SiO2, Fe3O4/AlN, and CuO/AlN etc. were prepared by the same method. The Co/AlN catalyst was obtained by reducing of corresponding Co3O4/AlN under H2 flow with a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 400 °C for 2 h. Other catalysts with different supports were prepared by the same method. Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, XPS, Raman, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, and N2-adsorption/desorption. The TEM images of the catalysts were measured using the FEI Tecnai G2 F20 electron microscope operated at 200 kV. All the samples were prepared by ultrasonically dispersing the powder material in ethanol and subsequently dropping the solution on a carbon-coated Au grid. The XRD was carried out on Rigaku D/max 2500 with nickel filtered Cu-Kα (λ = 0.154 nm) operated at 40 kV and 20 mA. The identification of XRD peaks was accomplished by comparing the diffraction patterns with those of the standard powder XRD files (ICSD database). The XPS spectra were performed using an ESCALab 220I-XL electron spectrometer from VG Scientific using 300 W AlKα radiation source (1486.6 eV) with a hemispherical energy analyzer. All the binding energies were corrected by using the C1 s peak (284.8 eV) as the reference. The Raman spectra were tested on a Laser microscopic Raman imaging spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with a 532 nm Ne laser and a high-grade Leica microscope (long working distance objective 50). The single crystal silicon was used for the position correction. The N2 adsorption/desorption tests were carried out at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 (USA). Prior to measurements, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 12 h under vacuum (lower than 10−5 tor). The specific surface areas were calculated using relative pressure values (P/P0) ranging from 0.05 to 0.3 according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was obtained by using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The H2-TPR was tested on an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) instrument. Prior to the test, 0.02 g samples were pretreated at 300 °C purging by He gas for 1 h and then reduced in the stream of 10% H2/Ar (50 mL/min) from 50 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The H2 consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector. The O2-TPO analysis was carried out as follows: the Co3O4/AlN catalyst was heated to 400 °C in H2 for 60 min, and then was cooled to 50 °C. After that, the gas was switched to 2% O2/He mixture gas with a rate of 30 mL/min. After the baseline was stable for 60 min, the sample was heated from 50 to 700 °C, and the O2 consumption was recorded by a TCD detector. Aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation and hydrogenation of N-heteroarenes Both reactions were carried out in 16 mL Teflon-lined autoclaves. For example, in a typical procedure for aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of N-heteroarenes, 0.02 g catalyst, 1 mmol substrate and 2 mL solvent were added into the reactor, which was sealed and charged with O2 to remove the air for five times. The reactor was then pressured to 5 atm of O2 and heated to the desired temperature. Upon reaction completion, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the gas in the autoclave was vented slowly. The liquid was analyzed by GC (GC9720, Zhejiang Fuli Analytical Instruments Co., Ltd., China) and GC–MS (Agilent 6890N-5975). The procedures for hydrogenation reaction were similar to those of dehydrogenation. Reuse and hot filtration experiments Upon reaction completion, the solid catalyst was filtrated and washed by ethanol (5 × 3 mL) and dried at 60 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The catalyst was then used directly in the next run, and the other operations were similar to those of standard run. The hot filtration experiments were accomplished as followings. After the dehydrogenation or hydrogenation reaction was performed for 6 h, the solid catalyst was filtrated and the filtrate continued being reacted for another 6 or 8 h. Upon reaction completion, the liquid was analyzed to detect whether the yield of product was increased. Results and discussion Catalyst characterizations The catalyst textural structures were analyzed by N2 adsorption/desorption tests at −196 °C, and the results were collected in Table 1 and the adsorption/desorption isothermal were given in Fig. S1. All the samples showed low BET surface areas due to the poor pore structure of AlN support. The different values of the tested samples were probably due to the error of measurement especially such a low BET surface area. Other carriers such as CeO2 and BN supported catalysts were also tested, and the results are given in Fig. S2 and Table S1. All the sample showed low BET surface areas, indicating the following different catalytic performances related less with the BET surface areas. The XRD patterns of AlN supported Co3O4 and Co catalysts are represented in Fig. 1 . In Fig. 1a, the profile of AlN showed the peaks at 33.3, 36.0, 37.9, 49.8, 59.4, 66.2, 69.8, 71.4, 72.6, and 81.0°, which could be attributed to the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (200), (112), (201), and (202) planes of AlN hexagonal wurtzite phase (ICDD PDF Card No. 00-003-1144) [33,39–41]. No Co3O4 peak could be found in Co3O4/AlN catalysts with the Co loadings lower than 4%, indicating that Co3O4 was dispersed well on AlN support. After increasing the Co loading to 6 or 8%, some new peaks appeared at 31.1, 36.8, 44.8, and 65.2° were assigned to the (220), (311), (400), and (440) planes of Co3O4 (ICDD PDF Card No. 00-042-1467). The result indicated that Co3O4 is successfully loaded on AlN support. The XRD patterns of Co/AlN catalysts which were reduced from Co3O4/AlN with different loadings presented well defined peaks of AlN (Fig. 1b). No Co° peak was obviously found, albeit with a high Co loading (8%). The reason for this phenomenon is probably that the particle size of Co3O4 NPs dwindled upon reduction, which is consistent with the following TEM results. The XRD results of other catalysts including Co3O4 and Co supported on CeO2, SiO2, and BN are given in Fig. S3, and the Co loadings of all these catalysts were 4%. A peak at 37.1° could be found in these three unreduced catalysts, which could be assigned to (311) plane of Co3O4. However, no Co peak could be detected after reduction, indicating that the Co NPs size decreases in the reduced catalysts, and this is similar to the Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images of the Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts. The image of Co3O4/AlN catalyst showed that Co3O4 NPs were loaded on AlN in the size range of 15–30 nm, which was calculated from more than 150 NPs (Fig. 2a and b). The HRTEM images of the Co3O4 NPs exhibited the lattice spacing of 2.44 and 4.68 Å, which were contributed to the (311) and (111) planes of Co3O4 (Fig. 2c and d). The results confirmed that Co3O4 exists in Co3O4/AlN, and this is in line with the XRD results. After reduction in H2 atmosphere, the morphology of Co/AlN catalyst was changed remarkably. The AlN support showed the nanosheet morphology with a thickness range of 3–5 nm. It is worth noting that although the morphology changed, the crystal of AlN retained according to the former XRD results. Besides, the particle size of Co° NPs was centered in the range of 6–9 nm, indicating that the size was dwindled after reduction [42]. The HRTEM images of the Co/AlN showed the lattice fringes of 2.47 and 2.03 Å in Fig. 2g and h, which were assigned to CoO (111) and Co° (002) planes, respectively. The results indicated that in Co3O4/AlN, the Co metal is in the form of Co3O4, while in Co/AlN, the Co species are composed of Co° and CoO. To analyze the surface composition of the catalyst, XPS was used to investigate the surface information, which is given in Fig. 3 . In Co 2p XPS spectrum of Co3O4/AlN catalyst, the peaks appeared at 780.4, 781.9, 796.0, and 797.9 eV could be assigned to be Co3+ 2p3/2, Co2+ 2p3/2, Co3+ 2p1/2, and Co2+ 2p1/2, respectively, while the peaks at 786.3 and 802.6 eV were attributed to the satellite peaks (Fig. 3a) [43,44]. The Al 2p XPS spectrum of Co3O4/AlN was deconvoluted into two peaks at 74.1 and 74.8 eV, which were attributed to AlN and AlO species (Fig. 3c) [45]. The N species appeared at 403 and 398.8 eV, and they could be assigned to the NN or unbonded N and AlN species (Fig. 3e) [46,47]. The O 1s XPS spectrum of Co3O4/AlN catalyst was also collected, which could be deconvoluted into three peaks at 532.6, 531.6, and 530.6 eV. These peaks were attributed to OH–, oxygen atoms in the neighbourhood of oxygen vacancies (VO), and MO especially the CoOAl species, respectively [48,49]. The Co 2p XPS spectrum of Co/AlN showed the peaks at 779.8, 781.4, 795.1, and 797.2 eV, which were assigned to Co3+ 2p3/2, Co2+ 2p3/2, Co3+ 2p1/2, and Co2+ 2p1/2, respectively. No Co° species was detected from the XPS spectra because the surface Co° species was partial oxidized in the air. However, the Co3+/Co2+ ratio was decreased remarkably, indicating that after reduction Co3+ was reduced to Co2+ and/or Co°. The Al 2p and N 1s XPS spectra of Co/AlN were almost the same as those of Co3O4/AlN, indicating that AlN was very stable during the reduction (Fig. 3c vs d, and e vs f). The O 1s XPS spectrum of Co/AlN were fitted into three peaks at 532.8, 531.4, and 530.2 eV, which were attributed to OH−, oxygen atoms in the neighbourhood of oxygen vacancies (VO), CoO and/or AlO species [48,49]. Interestingly, the peaks of CoO, AlO, and OH− were reduced, implying that after reduction, the CoO species were reduced and the oxygen vacancies were generated. To discover the interaction between Co species and AlN support, the Co XPS spectra of Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN were comparatively studied, and the results are given in Fig. S4. Compared with the Co XPS in pure Co3O4 catalyst, the Co XPS peaks in Co3O4/AlN were shifted to higher binding energies, indicating that electron could be transferred to AlN support from Co3O4 [50]. However, in the Co XPS profile of Co/AlN catalyst, the peaks were shifted to the lower binding energies than that of Co XPS in the pure Co catalyst, revealing that the electrons are transferred to Co from the AlN support. The results indicated that in the Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts, the electrons can be transferred between Co3O4, Co, and AlN via the CoOAl species. The catalysts were also analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy, and the results are shown in Fig. S6. All the tested samples including AlN, Co3O4/AlN, and Co/AlN exhibited a strong peak around 740 cm−1, which was assigned to the absorption of AlN groups [51]. The fingerprint stretching vibrations of CoO generally appeared at 574 and 666 cm−1 were overlapped by AlN bond [52]. Raman scattering is closely related to the microstructure of nanocrystalline materials, and the Raman spectra of AlN, Co/AlN, and Co3O4/AlN catalysts are given in Fig. 4 . The profile of AlN showed two obvious peaks at 656 and 615 cm−1, which were attributed to the A1(TO) and E22 modes of AlN [41]. After loading of Co3O4, besides the AlN peaks, some new peaks appealed at 190, 470, 514, 607, and 676 cm−1, which were attributed to F2g, Eg, F2g, F2g, and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively [15]. After the reduction, Co/AlN showed Co3O4 peaks and this was due to the oxidation of CoO and Co° under local laser heating [53]. Interestingly, a weak peak at 656 cm−1 was assigned to the A1(TO) mode of AlN, indicating Co was partly incorporated into the crystal lattice of AlN and deformed the surface structure [54]. The differences of Raman spectra between Co3O4/AlN or Co/AlN and AlN support indicated that the existence of strong interface interaction between Co3O4 or Co and AlN [55]. The Raman spectra of Co3O4 supported on SiO2, CeO2, and BN were also recorded and the results are given in Fig. S5. The peaks between 480−700 cm−1 in the supported Co3O4 catalysts could be attributed to the F2g, Eg, and Alg modes of Co3O4, while no Co3O4 peak was found in the reduced catalysts. The catalysts were also tested by ultraviolet-visible light diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS), and the results are given in Fig. 5 . In Fig. 5a, the AlN support exhibits strong absorptions in the UV range and weak absorptions in the visible range, and has two main absorptions at around 210 and 250 nm. After loading of Co3O4 and Co, the absorption of visible range increased, which was stem from the Co metals. The Kubelka–Munk plots indicated the band gap (Eg) of the tested catalysts (Fig. 5b). According to the Tauc’s equation, the Eg of pure AlN and Co3O4 were 3.92 and 1.56 eV, while those of Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN were 3.65 and 3.76 eV, indicating that the loaded Co species could reduce the Eg of AlN. The reason for this phenomenon was probably that the introduction of Co3O4 and Co could form AlN crystal defects [56]. H2-TPR experiments were conducted to evaluate the reducibility of Co species of supported Co3O4 catalysts, and the results are given in Fig. 6 a. In the profile of AlN, no peak was found, showing that H2 could not reduce AlN. Two peaks emerged around 276 and 364 °C in pure Co3O4, which could be assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co° [57]. However, after the Co3O4 was loaded on AlN support, the reduced peaks were shifted to 469 and 503 °C, indicating that AlN support could impede the reduction of cobalt oxides remarkably, which was derived from the strong interaction between cobalt oxides and AlN support [58]. The difficult in reduction of CoO bond probably related to the formation of CoOAl bonds, and the CoO and AlO bonds were confirmed by the former XPS results. It should be noted that the Co3O4 supported on diverse carriers such as SiO2, CeO2, and BN were also investigated. However, all of them showed the reduction peaks at lower temperatures, indicating that Co3O4/AlN probably processes the strongest interaction between Co3O4 and AlN than the others. Afterwards, O2-TPO experiments were conducted to evaluate the oxidative of reduced catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 6b. Three obvious oxidation peaks emerged around 284, 447, and 570 °C in the pure Co catalyst. However, in the curve of Co/AlN catalyst, no obvious peak was observed, indicating that the reduced Co/AlN catalyst could not be oxidized, indicating that the Co° species was protected by the stable CoOAl bonds. The similar results could be found in the O2-TPO profiles of Co/SiO2 and Co/BN. As for the Co/CeO2 catalyst, an oxidation peak appeared at 102 °C, indicating the Co could be oxidized, and this originate from the different metal-support interactions. The above characterizations indicated that a strong interaction between Co species with AlN support exists, which will probably affect the catalytic performances. Catalytic performances of Co3O4/AlN in aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ Our studies commenced with evaluation of various catalysts for the aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ to quinoline as a model reaction, and the results are collected in Table 2 . The sole Co3O4 catalyst was evaluated, and it gave 64% THQ conversion and 77% quinoline selectivity (Table 2, entry 1). However, the Co3O4/AlN catalyst with 4% Co loadings showed a conversion of 99% and the highest selectivity of 88%, demonstrating that it showed the best dehydrogenation performances under the given conditions (Table 2, entry 2). In the absence of O2, the reaction did not occur at all, revealing the reaction was aerobic oxidation (Table 2, entry 3). For comparison, the catalysts with different Co metal loadings, such as 1, 2, 6, and 8% were also investigated. All of them showed a high THQ conversion but moderate selectivity of target product (Table 2, entries 4–7). Co3O4 metal loaded on various supports such as Al2O3, CeO2, SiO2, and BN etc. were also investigated, but all of them offered a low conversion and/or selectivity, resulting in a low yield of quinoline (Table 2, entries 8–11). Subsequently, we checked the catalytic performances of AlN supported other metallic oxides. Among these catalysts, NiO/AlN, Mn3O4/AlN, CuO/AlN, and Fe3O4/AlN showed high conversions of THQ but relatively low to moderate selectivities to quinoline (Table 2, entries 12–15), while La2O3/AlN exhibited a low conversion (61%) but a high selectivity (98%) (Table 2, entry 16). The results indicated that the combination of Co3O4 and AlN presented the best catalytic performances in aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ to quinoline, which was stem from the strong interaction between Co3O4 and AlN support. From the characterization results, the presence of CoOAl bonds are partly accountable for the interaction. The effect of reaction conditions on the catalytic performances of aerobic dehydrogenation of THQ was investigated, and the results are given in Fig. 7 . The THQ conversion was increased with enhancing the reaction temperature from 80 to 120 °C, and the highest conversion was obtained after the temperature reached 120 °C. However, the selectivity decreased with elevating the temperature for the overoxidation under the high temperature [2]. In our experiments, the overoxidized products such as 3,4-dihydroquinolin-1(2H)-ol etc. were detected, which were confirmed by GC–MS. To obtain the highest yield of quinoline, we chose 120 °C as the optimized temperature. The dependence of reaction time on conversion, selectivity, and yield is exhibited in Fig. 7b. With prolonging the reaction time, the conversion increased tardily, while the selectivity decreased for the formation of byproducts, and the optimized reaction time was 12 h. The solvent had a great effect on the catalytic performance, and in the present work, we also investigated the effects of solvent on the reaction, including methanol (ME), dimethylformamide (DMF), mesitylene (MST), isopropyl alcohol (IPA), ethyl acetate (EA), and cyclohexane (CY) etc (Fig. 7c). The results indicated the reaction could be achieved smoothly in methanol solvent. By using Co3O4/AlN, we investigated its universality in the titled aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of N-heterocyclic substrates, and the results are collected in Table 3 . The substituted quinolines with electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups were successfully dehydrogenated. For example, a methyl-group at the 6-position of THQ gave almost total conversion (97%) and an 87% selectivity to the target product (Table 3, entry 1). Meanwhile, the methyl group at the 2-position of THQ provided a high conversion (94%) and selectivity (99%) to 2-methylquinoline after extending the reaction time to 16 h for the steric hindrance (Table 3, entry 2). 6-Hydroxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline offered total conversion (100%) of the substrate but 70% selectivity to the corresponding product, and 7-nitro-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline showed a 90% conversion and 99% selectivity after 16 h of reaction (Table 3, entries 3 and 4). Notably, the developed catalytic system could also catalyze the aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of isoquinoline and indole to corresponding products with high yields of 85% and 99%, indicating that the catalyst owns a good universality (Table 3, entries 5 and 6). Additionally, 2-methylindole provided a moderate yield (44%) to 2-methyl-1H-indole, while 7-chloroindoline and 5-bromoindoline gave 79% yield to 7-chloro-1H-indole and 3% yield to 5-bromo-1H-indole, respectively, revealing that the steric hindrance and electron withdrawing groups retarded the reaction (Table 3, entries 7–9). Notably, the gram-scale experiment provided 79% yield of quinoline, indicating that the present protocol possesses a great potential application in industry (Table 3, entry 10). Catalytic activities of Co/AlN in hydrogenation of quinolines It is well known that the low valence of Co species can catalyze the hydrogenation reactions. Herein, the reduced supported Co3O4 catalysts were further used in hydrogenation of quinoline, a reverse reaction for dehydrogenation of THQ, and the results are given in Table 4 . Interestingly, 4% Co/AlN catalyst produced almost quantitative conversion of quinoline and 100% THQ selectivity (Table 4, entry 1). No product was detected in the absence of catalyst, indicating that the reaction could not occur spontaneously (Table 4, entry 2). For comparison, AlN did not show any activity at all (Table 4, entry 3), and the sole Co catalyst exhibited a low activity, confirming that the catalytic activity is derived from the strong interaction between Co and AlN (Table 4, entry 4). Isopropanol is a widely used hydrogen source in hydrogenation. However, it was not the reducing agent because no product was detected by changing H2 to N2, indicating that H2 is the only reductant for the reaction (Table 4, entry 5). Co metal loaded on other supports such as Al2O3, CeO2, SiO2, and BN etc. were also investigated. Among these catalysts, Co/BN showed the best performances with 92% THQ conversion and 100% quinoline selectivity (Table 4, entry 6). Co/SiO2 could catalyze the reaction with a moderate yield (64%) to THQ, while Co/Al2O3 or Co/CeO2 showed a very poor or no activity, respectively (Table 4, entries 7 and 8). After that, we investigated the catalytic performances of AlN supported other metals such as Cu, Fe, Ni, Zn, and Mn. The Cu/AlN catalyst provided 61% THQ yield under the given conditions, however, the other catalysts did not have any activity at all (Table 4, entries 11–14). The results indicated that Co/AlN shows the highest hydrogenation activity in the synthesis of THQ, which is ascribed to the strong interaction between Co and AlN support. The effects of reaction conditions on quinoline hydrogenation were also studied, and the results are given in Fig. 8 . The temperature affected the catalytic performances remarkably. The highest yield was obtained at 100 °C in the range of 80–100 °C, indicating that the reaction needs enough energy to climb the activation energy barrier (Fig. 8a). The yield of THQ enhanced with the pressure of H2 increasing, and the highest yield obtained at PH2 was 4 MPa (Fig. 8b). The highest yield was reached after 12 h of reaction (Fig. 8c). The alcohol solvents showed good performances in quinoline hydrogenation reaction, for example, 73% yield of THQ was obtained in ethanol and 84% in methanol. However, the best performance was achieved in isopropyl alcohol. All the non-alcoholic solvents such as THF, DMF, dichloromethane, and ethyl acetate showed poor performances in the reaction (Fig. 8d). The universality of catalyst was also investigated in hydrogenation of N-heterocycles, and the results are collected in Table 5 . All the quinolines with a methyl at the 3-, 4-, and 6- positions of quinoline gave excellent yields to corresponding products, indicating that the electron donating group is beneficial for the reaction (Table 5, entries 1–3). A higher temperature was needed in the reaction of 8-methylquinoline hydrogenation for the steric hindrance between the methyl group and N atom of quinoline (Table 5, entry 4). 7-Nitroquinoline exhibited an ignorable yield to the corresponding product, demonstrating that the electron withdrawing group inhibits the reaction (Table 5, entry 5). The NH2- group at the 6-position of quinoline, however, provided a very low yield (Table 5, entry 6), which was probably due to the strong coordinating effect between the amine group and active site on catalyst. Electron-withdrawing groups such as chloride and bromide at the 6-position of the quinoline showed 70 and 22% yields to corresponding products (Table 5, entries 7 and 8). Besides the quinolines, the present protocol could be extended to the hydrogenation of isoquinolines and indoles, and offered very high yields to isoquinolines (99%) and indoles (99%) (Table 5, entries 9 and 10). Interestingly, the gram-scale experiment was also conducted, and a satisfying THQ yield (82%) for THQ was obtained (Table 5, entry 11), indicating that the catalyst has a great potential application in industry. Reusability studies and hot filtration experiments of both Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts To investigate the stability of Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts, we studied the reusabilities of these catalysts in aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of THQ and hydrogenation of quinoline under the optimized conditions, and the results are given in Fig. 9 . From the results, it could be found that both of Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts showed good reusabilities. Both catalysts could be used at least five times without obvious loss in activity (Fig. 9a and c). The hot filtration experiments were tested, and the results are given in Fig. 9. After filtrating of the catalysts, no additional conversions were observed upon reaction completion, indicating that Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts proceeded in true heterogeneous ways (Fig. 9b and d). Conclusion Two redox Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN catalysts were developed and applied in the reverse aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation/hydrogenation of N-heterocycles reactions with high activities. These catalysts showed good universalities and reusabilities for the titled reactions. Importantly, good performances were obtained in gram-scale experiments, indicating that they possess great potential applications in industry. The catalytic activities were stem from the strong interaction between Co species and AlN support, and particularly the existence of CoOAl bonds was partly accountable for these interactions. The present work is believed to provide some new approaches for constructing redox Co-based catalyst and conversion and utilization of N-heterocycles. coredata.dc:description: N-heterocycles with quinoline and tetrahydroquinoline structures are highly important in pharmaceutical and chemical industries, and their highly efficient mutual transformations are vital but still challenging. In the present work, AlN supported redox cobalt catalysts (Co3O4/AlN and Co/AlN) were prepared, which could achieve the reversible aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation/hydrogenation of N-heterocycles with good performances. The catalytic performances were stem from the strong interaction between Co species with AlN support, which were confirmed by the characterizations of Raman, XPS, UV–vis DRS, and H2-TPR etc. Both of the catalysts showed good stabilities and reusabilities for the titled reactions. Besides, the gram-scale experiments achieved with good yields to corresponding products, revealing the present protocol possesses great potential applications in industry. The strategy of using redox Co-based catalyst not only provides a potential catalyst for the reversible hydrogenation/oxidative dehydrogenation reactions but also replenishes methods for constructing of other redox catalyst, especially with AlN as a carrier.
coredata.dc:title: Reversible aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation/hydrogenation of N-heterocycles over AlN supported redox cobalt catalysts
